folder: Fulton Fish Market., Manhattan, NY
text:
Fulton Fish Market: Manhattan's supply of fresh fish being unloaded and transferred to horse-drawn wagons. Note the Woolworth Tower in the background.

About, 1920

Ewing Galloway
title: Fulton Fish Market.

folder: South Street & Beckman Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Rear view of South Street, east side, at the foot of Beekman Street, as seen from the North Dock on the East River. The view shows several of the buildings of the Fulton Street Fish Market, bordering on the river front. 1923.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, a further view southward.

February 16, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, still further south, and showing the site of the old Fulton Street Ferry.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Fulton Fish Market., Manhattan, NY
text:
Fulton Fish Market: Fish buyers examining packaged goods in the middle of Peck Slip. These boxes, after being auctioned are then delivered to the purchaser's place of business by the independent truckman.

1923
Views 1, 2, 3

folder: Fulton fish market - [North dock - East River.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Fulton Fish Market: Various activities at the North Dock, the East River pier thru which New York's fish supply enters the City. This is located in the downtown area and the photographer shows prominent skyscrapers in the background.

folder: Fulton fish market - [North dock - Unloading and preparing cracked ice for the city's fish supply.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Fulton Fish Market: Men unloading and preparing cracked ice for the cities fish supply. This activity is on North Dock (Pier 18), an East River pier at the foot of Beekman Street. In the background are buildings on the river side of South Street, that are devoted to the pursuit of this enterprise.

1923
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr
title: Fulton fish market - [North dock - Unloading and preparing cracked ice for the city's fish supply.]

P. L. Sperr.

(3) Drying nets in preparation for next fishing trip. Fulton Fish Market. September 28, 1933.

folder: Fulton fish market - [East River Pier No.18 - North dock.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Fulton Fish Market: East River Pier No. 18 (North Dock). A set of 3 views taken at the above location showing various aspects of this fish supply market. Most of the unloading is at this pier, the sale of same being in buildings on both sides of South Street.

Being adjacent to the financial area, photographers find this a picturesque area, as shown in View 2 where the 60 Wall Tower blends into the rigging of a fishing schooner.

View 1: About 1923
View 2: March 10, 1933
View 3: October 1, 1934

P. L. Sperr
title: Fulton fish market - [East River Pier No.18 - North dock.]

folder: Fulton fish market - [Fishing schooner Viking.], Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Loading fish into barrels, and packing it with ice, at Fulton Fish Market. About 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) Dumping old ice from hold of fishing trawler, at dock of Fulton Fish Market. September 28, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The Municipal Building through the rigging of the "Viking"; one of the fishing schooners that supply New York. September 28, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Fulton fish market - [Old fashioned bean trawler.], Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Despite all modern marvels in navigation, the old fashioned beam trawler is still unanimously used by the fishermen serving Fulton Fish Market.
January 1924.

P. L. Sperr.

(2 & 3)
Two similar Wintry scenes at North Dock. Note the Brooklyn Bridge in the background.
February 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Piers 17-18 - Manhattan - South Street - [Woolworth Building.], Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Piers Nos. 18 and 17, (left to right) East River, east side of South Street. Pier No. 18 (North Dock) is shown between the two units of the Fulton Fish Market. A general view westward of lower Manhattan is seen, with the Woolworth Building on the right.

September 24, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, viewed northward, with positions of piers reversed.

July 8, 1926.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
(1) Roasted seeds, nuts, etc., being sold by push-cart peddler at Orchard and Grand Streets. April 25, 1934. P. L. Sperr.

(2) Peanut vendor, shown on Fulton Fish Market dock. April 25, 1934. P. L. Sperr.

(3) All varieties of nuts, strung or otherwise; vendors usually "mush-room" forth during festivals in the Italian quarters; seen taken at Roosevelt Street and New Bowery. August 16, 1935. P. L. Sperr.
title: Occupations - Peddlers - Food - Refreshments - Nuts.

folder: Fulton fish market in Manhattan - [North Dock - East River Pier No.18.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Fulton Fish Market: A westward view from the extremity of North Dock (pier No. 18, East River) showing early morning activity at Manhattan's wholesale fish market. Trawler's bring this commodity from the northern Atlantic waters and workingmen pack same preparatory to truck distribution. Forming a background are various office structures, prominent of which is the Woolworth Building.

About 1935

Ewing Galloway
title: Fulton fish market in Manhattan - [North Dock - East River Pier No.18.]

folder: Fulton fish market in Manhattan - [North Atlantic fish trawler - North Dock - East River Pier No.18.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Fulton Fish Market: A North Atlantic fish trawler being unloaded at the North Dock (pier 18, East River). In the background are office buildings forming the famous Wall Street outline.

About, 1935

Ewing Galloway
title: Fulton fish market in Manhattan - [North Atlantic fish trawler - North Dock - East River Pier No.18.]

folder: Fulton fish market in Manhattan - [North dock - East River Pier No.18.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Fulton Fish Market: East River Pier No. 18 (North Dock).---View south.

Two views southward from the above location showing the close proximity of this market to the financial area at Wall Street.

Hazily outlined in the background are the No. 120 Wall Street Building (American Sugar Refining) and the 60 Wall Tower (No. 70 Pine Street, Cities Service Co.).

1936
Views: 1-2

W. P. A. Photo
Federal Writers Project
title: Fulton fish market in Manhattan - [North dock - East River Pier No.18.]

folder: Fulton fish market in Manhattan - [North dock - East River Pier No.18 - Unloading schooners.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Fulton Fish Market: East River Pier No. 18 (North Dock) -- Schooners unloading.

Three views showing unloading activity on this dock from which the majority of the City's fish is supplied. The photographer is viewing generally northward towards the Brooklyn Bridge and the civic center, Foley Square.

At the latter appears the dim out line of the Municipal Building and the Federal Courts Building.

W. P. A. Photo
Federal Writers Project

1936
Views: 1-2-3
title: Fulton fish market in Manhattan - [North dock - East River Pier No.18 - Unloading schooners.]

folder: Fulton fish market in Manhattan - [North dock - East River Pier No.18.], Manhattan, NY
text:
Fulton Fish Market: East River Pier No. 18 (North Dock).

A set of 3 views photographed at the above location and showing various activities at this fish receiving point.

Note the market building collapse in the smaller of these views. This structure was at the rivers edge and was primarily used for the sale and delivery of the commodity that gives this zone its name. The buildings shown here are on the opposite side of South Street and house the overflow from the market.

1936
Views: 1-2-3

W. P. A. Photo
Federal Writers Project
title: Fulton fish market in Manhattan - [North dock - East River Pier No.18.]

folder: Fulton fish market in Manhattan., Manhattan, NY
text:
Fulton Fish Market:  Fisherman weighing and packing the perishable commodity that identifies this area of Manhattan.  Across the background, in the early morning mist, appear the outlines of, the 120 Wall Street Building; the Farmers Loan and Trust Company Building; and the 60 Wall Street Tower.

About 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad A.R.P.S.
title: Fulton fish market in Manhattan.

folder: South Street & Beckman Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
South Street, east side, north from the foot of Beekman Street, showing the northerly unit of the Fulton Fish Market pier buildings. View 2 shows the replacement. The Brooklyn Bridge dominates the background.

1: August 2, 1937
2: Sept. 3, 1940

P. L. Sperr
